entry.title: Armenia, US announce joint military drills

media:group.media:title: Armenia, US announce joint military drills
media:group.media:description:
ğŸ“ Armenian Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan resumed calls for a new constitution amid repeated demands from Azerbaijan to remove references to Nagorno-Karabakh. ğŸ“ Armenia and the United States will hold joint military exercises next week, similar to drills held last September. ğŸ“ Armenia sent congratulatory messages to Masoud Pezeshkian, the reformist winner of Iranâ€™s presidential election, and Keir Starmer, the United Kingdomâ€™s new Labour prime minister.

media:group.media:title: Armenia to celebrate Vardavar #shorts
media:group.media:description:
Every year for one day Armenians get a break from the summer heat by celebrating Vardavar. This holiday involves drenching and getting drenched in public. It includes everyone you know and those you donâ€™t know. Vardavar was a pagan festival in ancient times, celebrating Astghik, the Armenian goddess of water, fertility, and love. Armenia eventually adopted Christianity as its state religion, but this festival remained intact. The Armenian Apostolic Church identified Vardavar with the Transfiguration of Jesus and incorporated it into one of its five feast days. Vardavar is now celebrated across Armenia every summer. Young people use buckets and stay close to fountains and ponds. Some prefer to position themselves on higher ground on their balconies. Some even use hoses. The most important thing to remember is that on Vardavar, nobody is safeâ€”make sure to leave your nice clothes at home! Vardavar takes place 14 weeks after Easter each year. This summer, itâ€™s on July 7. Have fun!

media:group.media:description:
In this episode of Insights, host Eric Hacopian analyzes Secretary of Armenia's National Security Councilâ€™s comments last week regarding the challenges Armenia faced last year. He also takes an in-depth look at what factors led to the ethnic cleansing of Artsakh and the widespread displacement of Armenians. entry.title: Uncertainties mount in bordering Kirants amid border demarcation

media:group.media:title: Uncertainties mount in bordering Kirants amid border demarcation
media:group.media:description:
After a period of anti-government protests in Armeniaâ€™s Tavush region, the sound of border construction is now heard again. In May, residents in Kirants village, bordering Azerbaijan, took to the streets to protest Yerevanâ€™s border delimitation and demarcation process, which includes the handing over of vital roads, bridges, and farmland to Azerbaijan. The demarcation has already split part of Kirants village and has led to the evacuation of a number of residents. CivilNet is in the region to understand the impact of this process on people.
